page.title: 02BERKELEY CASTLE
page.content: Berkeley Castle, which overlooks the Little Avon River just to the south of the town, is said to be the oldest castle in England which is still inhabited. There has probably been a castle of some sort on the site since Norman times but the present castle building dates from the end of the 12th century and was built by Robert Fitzhardinge on the orders of Henry II. Edward II was imprisoned there in 1327 in the care of Lord Berkeley. On September 21,1327, Edward was murdered by his guards, Sir Thomas Gourney and Lord Maltravers. The castle is still owned by the Berkeley family who also own much of the farm land in the area. One curious feature of the parish church, St Mary's, is that the tower is built separately some 100 yards away, lest it be of advantage to anyone beseiging the castle.
